channel.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories
channel.description: Top stories in the U.S. and world news, politics, health, science, business, music, arts and culture. Nonprofit journalism with a mission. This is NPR.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

image.title: NPR Topics: Home Page Top Stories

item.title: With a win over Sweden, the U.S. men's hockey team will play for an Olympic medal
item.description: A thrilling overtime goal by defenseman Quinn Hughes puts Team USA through to a semifinal game against Slovakia. On the other side of the bracket, Canada had its own close call, but moves on to face Finland.
item.content:encoded:
A thrilling overtime goal by defenseman Quinn Hughes puts Team USA through to a semifinal game against Slovakia. On the other side of the bracket, Canada had its own close call, but moves on to face Finland.

(Image credit: Hassan Ammar/AP)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: Zuckerberg grilled about Meta's strategy to target 'teens' and 'tweens'
item.description: The billionaire tech mogul's testimony was part of a landmark social media addiction trial in Los Angeles. The jury's verdict in the case could shape how some 1,600 other pending cases from families and school districts are resolved.
item.content:encoded:
The billionaire tech mogul's testimony was part of a landmark social media addiction trial in Los Angeles. The jury's verdict in the case could shape how some 1,600 other pending cases from families and school districts are resolved.

(Image credit: Frederic J. Brown)
item.dc:creator: Bobby Allyn

item.title: The Trump administration is increasingly trying to criminalize observing ICE
item.description: ICE officers often tell people tracking and watching them that they are breaking federal law in doing so, but legal experts say the vast majority of observers are exercising their constitutional rights.
item.content:encoded:
ICE officers often tell people tracking and watching them that they are breaking federal law in doing so, but legal experts say the vast majority of observers are exercising their constitutional rights.

(Image credit: Octavio Jones)
item.dc:creator: Meg Anderson

item.title: 8 backcountry skiers found dead and 1 still missing after California avalanche
item.description: Authorities say the bodies of eight backcountry skiers have been found and one remains missing after an avalanche near Lake Tahoe in California. Six others were found alive.
item.content:encoded:
Authorities say the bodies of eight backcountry skiers have been found and one remains missing after an avalanche near Lake Tahoe in California. Six others were found alive.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: FDA reverses course on Moderna flu shot
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration's about-face comes a little more than a week after the agency refused to consider the company's application to market the new kind of influenza vaccine.
item.content:encoded:
The Food and Drug Administration's about-face comes a little more than a week after the agency refused to consider the company's application to market the new kind of influenza vaccine.

(Image credit: Bill Sikes)
item.dc:creator: Sydney Lupkin

item.title: Trump would like the government he leads to pay him billions
item.description: President Trump is asking the federal government for billions of dollars in damages, putting his own Justice Department on the spot and creating an unprecedented ethical morass.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump is asking the federal government for billions of dollars in damages, putting his own Justice Department on the spot and creating an unprecedented ethical morass.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Australia bans a citizen with alleged IS links from returning from Syria
item.description: The Australian is among a group of 34 women and children who had planned to fly from Damascus to Australia on Monday but were turned back by Syrian authorities to the Roj detention camp due to procedural problems.
item.content:encoded:
The Australian is among a group of 34 women and children who had planned to fly from Damascus to Australia on Monday but were turned back by Syrian authorities to the Roj detention camp due to procedural problems.

(Image credit: Baderkhan Ahmad/AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Russia's hybrid warfare rattles Poland and NATO
item.description: Russia is stepping up covert attacks across Europe — rail sabotage, drones, cyberstrikes — testing NATO. Polish officials warn "disposable agents" are sowing fear and weakening support for Ukraine.
item.content:encoded:
Russia is stepping up covert attacks across Europe — rail sabotage, drones, cyberstrikes — testing NATO. Polish officials warn "disposable agents" are sowing fear and weakening support for Ukraine.

(Image credit: Wojtek Radwanski)
item.dc:creator: Rob Schmitz

item.title: 'Let them shower in hotels': Johannesburg Premier faces backlash amid water crisis
item.description: In South Africa, as taps run dry in Johannesburg, Africa's richest city, a tone deaf remark by a senior politician there unleashes fury.
item.content:encoded:
In South Africa, as taps run dry in Johannesburg, Africa's richest city, a tone deaf remark by a senior politician there unleashes fury.

(Image credit: Emmanuel Croset)
item.dc:creator: Kate Bartlett

item.title: Greetings from Cairo, where lights and decorations transform the city during Ramadan
item.description: As Ramadan begins, traditional lanterns called fawanees brighten Cairo. They have become a symbol of Ramadan and are an almost-mandatory home decoration for the holy month in Egypt.
item.content:encoded: As Ramadan begins, traditional lanterns called fawanees brighten Cairo. They have become a symbol of Ramadan and are an almost-mandatory home decoration for the holy month in Egypt.
item.dc:creator: Greg Dixon
